prj:VisitConstraint.prj:note: We note that both Band 3 and 6 observations are preferably to be taken on the same day, since magnetar emission is known to be highly variable.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Default correlator setup for continuum observation is sufficient.
Since we do not expect any extended emission, the observations can be carried out with any array configurations.
We seek to search for magnetar emission down to a sensitivity of 0.1mJy at 3 sigma level, similar to previous studies (e.g., Camilo et al. 2006). This sets our desired sensitivity of 0.033mJy.

This ToO proposal is triggered by new detection of radio emission from a magnetar during an outburst. This ensures that the source is not radio-quiet and the ALMA results could be directly compared to the other radio observations that made the trigger. After the trigger, we request to make the first observations within reasonable time (~2 weeks). Both Band 3 and 6 observations are preferably to be taken on the same day, since magnetar emission is known to be highly variable.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 3 follow-up flux density measurements
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band 3 follow-up flux density measureemnts for the 2nd and 3rd epochs, no polarisation measurements needed.

prj:VisitConstraint.prj:note: These are follow-up observations, should be carried out at intervals of 2 weeks, a month, and two months since the previous observation. We would like to have both the Band 3 and 6 observations taken on the same day, since magnetar emission is known to be highly variable.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Default correlator setup for continuum observation is sufficient.
Since we do not expect any extended emission, the observations can be carried out with any array configurations.
We seek to search for magnetar emission down to a sensitivity of 0.1mJy at 3 sigma level, similar to previous studies (e.g., Camilo et al. 2006). This sets our desired sensitivity of 0.033mJy.

After the initial observation, we request three follow-up flux density measurements at intervals of two weeks, a month, and two months since the last observation. These give sufficient measurements probe the form of the flux density evolution. Both Band 3 and 6 observations are preferably to be taken on the same day, since magnetar emission is known to be highly variable.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Default correlator setup for continuum observation is sufficient.
Since we do not expect any extended emission, the observations can be carried out with any array configurations.
We seek to search for magnetar emission down to a sensitivity of 0.1mJy at 3 sigma level, similar to previous studies (e.g., Camilo et al. 2006). This sets our desired sensitivity of 0.033mJy.

After the initial observation, we request three follow-up flux density measurements at intervals of two weeks, a month, and two months since the last observation. These give sufficient measurements probe the form of the flux density evolution. Both Band 3 and 6 observations are preferably to be taken on the same day, since magnetar emission is known to be highly variable.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Magnetars are strongly magnetized neutron stars that occasionally exhibit remarkable outbursts. A handful of these sources have radio pulsations and infrared (IR) emission detected following outbursts. They show many peculiar properties including flat radio spectra extending to over 100 GHz, which are difficult to explain by standard pulsar theories. We propose ALMA observations of magnetars during an outburst to measure the spectral and polarization properties at high radio frequencies, which will provide essential inputs for building a physical model for the radio emission. The results will bridge the gap between the previous radio and IR detections, help clarifying whether there is a connection between them. Specifically, this could establish if both emission originate from the magnetosphere of a magnetar, or the IR emission arises from X-ray heated debris disks.
